title: derry city cemetery series minister revitalised burt presbyterian church
story: Robert William Ross was born in Co Cavan in  and upon completion of his training in the Presbyterian Church he was made a licentiate of the Derry Presbytery in  and was ordained at Burt on Christmas Eve .Reverend Ross’ immediate challenge was to oversee the much needed repairs to the church building. The Committee then asked architect William Barker to estimate the cost of the renovations to the old building as well as the cost of a plain new place of worship.Mr Barker’s financial quote for the construction project said that the revamp of the old church would cost £ and a new church would be £,. To put the overall estimate into perspective, today the combined  figure of just over £, would be worth over £,.The records of Burt Presbyterian Church show that a Committee meeting on February ,  it was decided upon the casting vote of Rev Ross to abandon the renovation scheme and the idea of building a new church was then put before the congregation at a meeting on February , .The go-ahead for the new building was dependent upon the congregation subscribing an additional £ more than they had already promised. When that was agreed by the congregation, plans to construct the new church were given the green light for the year .Financial pressure on the project was immediately eased when Lord Templemore subscribed the entire £, but further collections were made in Derry, Newtoncunningham, Crossroads, Raphoe, Strabane, St Johnston and Carrigans, Knowhead, Fahan and Inch.Rev Ross himself reported back that he had gathered another £ in Belfast and Lisburn.With the money in place, William Barker was tasked to prepare plans for a meeting house that could accommodate  people, to have a plain roof, double windows, buttressed walls finished with cement dashing and windows with cement plaster. The church pews were to be pitch pine with walnut top rails.The location of the new church, it was decided, was to be in the upper corner of the ground filled by the old building with the entrance door facing the present gateway in line with the entrance of the old meeting house. Two Porrett stoves sunk in each aisle were to provide the heating.The lineage of Presbyterianism in Burt is one that stretches back over three-and-half centuries. But, as the city of Derry began to grow after the Plantation of Ulster, the Presbyterians of Burt travelled there. In the city at this time, Episcopacy, or the governance of the church by a clerical hierarchy was established by law. But, services were conducted at St Columb’s Cathedral and St Augustine’s Church on the walls to suit the views of Presbyterians.Back in , a Presbyterian minister in Derry was deposed for failing to conform to the views of the Episcopacy and another  fled from the city to avoid being imprisoned.By , the Presbyterian Congregation in Derry was still languishing when attempts were begun to bring preachers over from Scotland.As evidence of the persecution of those of the Presbyterian tradition, a William Hampton, who had been brought into the city by Presbyterians such as Campsie, Burnside and Early was implicated for preaching at a large meeting house which they had built within the city’s walls and just a few yards away from the mansion of the established church’s Bishop.This ‘affront’ to the Anglican tradition could no longer apparently be tolerated by the church authorities.On Sunday, September , , the Bishop decided to take action and with the Mayor, a judge, the city’s Sherrf and other officers they visited the meeting house where they found the Presbyterian congregation praying with William Hampton.It was recorded that they were: “Praying and preaching openly, and not according to the established Liturgy and order of the Church of Ireland.”A “riotous” confrontation took place, the leaders arrested and the church was promptly shut down. This situation continued until August ,  when devoid of anyone to lead them in prayer, the Derry Presbyterians asked for Hampton’s services until another preacher could be appointed.In , Rev Robert Rule of Kirkcaldy in Scotland accepted a call to minister in Derry and was installed that year.Some  years before Rev Ross set foot in Burt and application was made to the Presbytery of Laggan by an Alderman of Derry, John Craigie and a merchant, Mr John Fisher together with William Cunningham of Burt to ide the Parish of Templemore into two congregations. This came about in  and the previously pilloried Rev William Hampton ed from Scotland and was ordained at Carnamaddy on October  that year.Another  odd years later, there was a dispute over parish boundaries within the Presbytery of Derry when in  the people of Elagh, Coshquin and Ballynagalliagh refused to belong to Derry. But, it took until January , for the Synod to order “that the liberties of the City on that side of the water wherein the City standeth should be the bounds of the Congregation.”It seems the Burt people weren’t happy with that decision and appealed it, but without success.Another point of interest about Presbyterianism in Burt is that in  the worshippers from Inch who had attended Burt since  formed their own congregation under the Derry Presbytery. The mode of transport to Burt from Inch Island had always been boats. It’s said that on Sunday’s someone sat at a window in the Gallery of Burt church watching the tide and when it was just right, the person stood up and announced that ‘the Inch folk may go now.’During the -year ministry of Rev Robert Graythe old church had fallen into a state of disrepair. There were no pews and the aisles were covered by cold flagstones. But, previous to that there was only an earthen floor and no heating at all.In , the church had a new roof and ceiling installed. Prior to that it was recorded that it was a common thing for the rain to pour down on the heads of the congregation.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshNevertheless, the Presbyterian denomination in the district was flourishing. In , the Parish of Burt had , Presbyterians,  people belonging to the Church of Ireland and , Catholics.When it came time to finalise the plans for the new church under the watch of Rev Ross in , the final estimate of William Barker was £, and tenders for the construction project were advertised on April .Three bids were received. One came from R Colhoun in Derry who bid £, for the church and £ for its boundary wall. Another came from Joseph Colhoun, also from Derry who bid £, for the church and £ for the boundary wall. The final tender came from Matthew McClelland from the city who tendered £, for the church and £ for the wall, who having made the lowest bid won the contract.It was agreed that contractor was bound to have the house roofed, the outside of the walls finished and the windows installed by September ,  and ready for opening by March , .In the presence of shirt industry magnate, William Tillie, the High Sherrf of County Derry and many members of the congregation and people from the surrounding area, the foundation stone was laid on July , .The builder, Joseph Colhoun presented Mr Tillie with an inscribed silver trowel to lay the stone and a sealed bottle acted as a time capsule which inside were placed copies of the Derry Standard, the Derry Journal, Londonderry Sentinel, Northern Whig, Missionary Herald, Christian Banner, a photo of the old church and some coins. Lunch was provided for the dignitaries in the lecture room which was highly decorated with flowers and plants.The contract deadline was narrowly missed and the church opened in early May, .The opening services on Sunday, May ,  were conducted by the then Moderator of the General Assembly, Rev Dr G Buick from Cullybackey and the following week by Rev William Colquhoun of Fitzroy Avenue, Belfast. The minister’s room and toilet in the church as well as the pulpit and choir  were provided as gts by Mrs JB Mullin of Buncrana who was the sister of Rev Ross and the we of John Brice Mullin the Deputy Lieutenant of County Donegal.Fundraising events for the upkeep of the church were however still of course necessary. In , it was reported that Rev Ross organised a very successful Sale of Work and Summer Fete which were held on July ,  and  that year.The events took place in the Lecture Hall and a marquee in the church grounds and began at .pm each day. The proceedings were opened on July  by Mrs McMaster of College Avenue in Derry and the Mayor of Derry, Alderman JP Thompson oversaw the events.There was an Empire Work Stall, a Shamrock Work Stall, a Provision stall, a Sweet Stall, a Children’s Stall and Refreshment Stall. The Amusement Committee organised a large number of competitions that included shooting events. On the nights of the  and  July, a iety concert took place in the Lecture Hall. Over the three days, a firm called Neely’s operated a sidecar service ferrying people from Bridgend Railyway Station to the church and back again. The combined rail and admission ticket cost d and a specially laid on train took people back to Derry from Bridgend each night at .pm.The funds raised in July,  helped to renovate the Lecture Hall and other church buildings and to properly lay out the church grounds.As with many other congregations of all denominations across Ireland, the First World War impacted upon Burt Presbyterian Church. To reflect this, in August of  the Church Committee proposed to obtain an organ and a Memorial Tablet at the entrance of the church.Three of the congregation, John Buchanan, Stewart Buchanan and Joseph Downey were killed between -. And, in October  it was reported that £ had been collected for the organ and the memorial. The tablet was unveiled on Sunday, January ,  by Mrs Bowen, we of Colonel William Bowen DSO and the preacher on this occasion was Captain Rev WP Hall and a Guard of Honour travelled to Burt from Ebrington Barracks in Derry for the event. The tablet also remembered  more men and women from Burt congregation who had served in WWI.After the Great War and the partition of Ireland in , many of the working-class families connected to Burt Church moved into Derry city and other part of the North and many more who had served in the war had not ed to the area as work was scarce in this era. The drop in numbers within the congregation was reflected by the names recorded in the Communion Roll Book between -.Rev R W Ross resigned from active duty as Minister of Burt Presbyterian Church on July ,  and he died aged  at the City and County Infirmary in Derry on Sunday, July  after a long illness. The Church Session and Committee met later that day and paid tribute to the long and diligent service that had he had given.A deputation from the church was due to travel to Belfast the next day to meet with the Presbyterian Union Commission and they went ahead with the plans despite Mr Ross’ death as there would not an opportunity for another meeting for at least another two months.The Union Commission was proposing that Burt and Netwoncunningham congregations should be amalgamated under one minister, but the Session and Committee of Burt flatly rejected the suggestion.In June of  the Committee looked at the issue of enquiring at the price of a memorial for the late Rev Ross and a stained glass window and in February of  a Mr Haslett submitted sketches for a memorial tablet and his proposals were accepted. The memorial tablet was unveiled by Rev Ross’ widow Bessie on Sunday, June , .Rev Robert William Ross had married Bessie in  and in his will left a total of £ s d. He was buried in Derry City Cemetery.Upon her husband’s passing Bessie lived firstly at Castlehill Road, Belfast and later at Bognor Regis and then Pallant, Chichester. Following her death on July ,  she was buried there. Bessie bequeathed a total of £, s d to her two sons, Leslie Norman Ross and Arthur Gordon Ross, who were both doctors.A third son, George Harold Ross was born on May ,  in Derry. George was educated at Campbell College in Belfast and began a career in banking after emigrating. He enlisted in the th Canadian Battalion at the rank of Liuetenant on November ,  and later transferred to the th Canadian Battalion.  He saw action at the Somme in July,  and in April,  at Vimy Ridge where he was wounded and suffered injuries to his left femur and left foot. He was demobilised in July,  and ed to Canada where he became a farmer.CAPTION: The Reverend Robert William Ross.

title: rare breed star cahir launches annual agricultural show
story: A young boy from Dungiven has helped to launch this weekend’s Co Londonderry and Limavady Agricultural Show.Young Cahir McGilligan, who found fame on the recent series of UTV’s Rare Breed, was on hand to launch the show which takes place tomorrow, Saturday, July .Avid farmer Cahir was delighted to be able to help out and is looking forward to participating himself.The annual show, which will be held at Aghanloo, Limavady, will see a number of events taking place throughout the day.These include horse and pony showing and jumping working hunter classes.googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshLivestock showingand a fencing competition will also take place.Other attractions include home industries, crafts, vegetables and flowers, fun and games and numerous trade stands and young farmers tug of war.Updates can be found on their Facebook page.Cahir McGilligan is pictured above with the Chairman Mr Alwyn McFarlane and Mr Stanley Warnock who want to encourage everyone to attend the show for a great family day out.

title: statistics reveal missed targets department concedes ambulance service currently resourced
story: The department of health has conceded that the current level of demand on the ambulance service exceeds available resources.The ambulance service has been dealing with a surge in emergency calls over recent years.Newly published Department of Healthstatistics reveal that between   and  , the number of emergency calls received by the NIAS increased by , from , to ,.In   the Western Local Commissioning Groupalone, which takes in Derry, received , calls – almost  a day.Aside from the Belfast LCG, the ambulance service in the Western area received the highest number of calls in the past year based on per ,-population.Category A calls are immediately le threatening and receive the NIAS’s highest priority with a performance target of arriving at .% of these calls within  minutes.During the last five years in NI, the percentage of Category A calls responded to within  minutesdecreased from .% in   to .% in  In   all LCGs fell well below this target, with the Western Trust the second-best performer at just .%.From December  to March  the performance across Northern Ireland has deteriorated. Most LCGs recorded percentages below  while the Western Trust consistently registered a score below % during that period, something that hadnt happened in the eight months prior.Category B are serious but not le-threatening calls and require a response within  minutes and category C calls are neither le threatening or serious and require a response within  minutes.Over the past year % of journeys in the Western area were deemed emergencies while the rest were non-emergencies.‘Competing priorities’In response to claims that the ambulance cover in Derry is insufficient and the service in general is facing serious funding pressures, the department of health said it looks to the NIAS to ensure that sufficient ambulance cover is provided throughout NI.A spokeswoman explained: "The Department recognises that demand for ambulance services is currently outstripping the available resources."We are currently considering the outcome of a public consultation by NIAS on a new clinical response model whichintroduced will ensure that that the most ill patients requiring an ambulance will be seen quickly as well as improving the overall efficiency of response times.”She continued: "This new service model will require signicant investment which will have to be found within the Department’s budget against other competing priorities for investment in health and social care services."Ahead of decisions to be taken on the new service model later this year the Department has committed to putting more paramedics on the ground and is funding  training places from its transformation fund."googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refresh

title: unacceptable behaviour making life misery derry housing estate
story: A Housing Association and the police have come under pressure to decisively deal with anti-social tenants who are making le a misery for residents in one of Derry’s newest housing estates.Video footage appeared online at the end of last week showing a group of men and women involved in a brawl outside Balliniska Heights.It is the latest in a string of similar incidents at the housing development which has built itself a reputation as an anti-social hotspot since welcoming its first tenants in April of .Sarah Doherty has been there since the beginning and she said there has been lawless behaviour throughout that time.She lives in one of the houses in Balliniska Avenue but the criminal elements are confined to the apartment block named Balliniska Heights. Sarah is afraid to let her child out to play in the park as a result.“Since I’ve been there I’ve noticed non-stop partying, people taking drugs, someone was stabbed in the head, a person died over-dosing, a couple fighting outside, a paedophile overlooking the park had to be removed too.“People off their heads on drugs crashed into my car recently too when my wain was with me. He was arrested.“And the fight last Thursday was the latest.”She added: “You can see them drinking and taking drugs during the day so you know something bad is going to happen."googletag.cmd.push .addSize.addSize.buildslot  googletag.defineSlot.defineSizeMapping.setTargeting.setTargeting.setTargeting.addServicegoogletag.displaygoogletag.pubads.refreshA court case is also ongoing after a man allegedly raped and attempted to kill a woman in Balliniska Heights. The alleged victim was discovered on the Northland Road with serious injuries.The case is still active with the accused due to appear at a Magistrate’s sitting this week. All seven charges from the first appearance on th April  remain.There is a collective view amongst residents in Balliniska Avenue and Heights that these anti-social iniduals must be removed but they feel Clanmil Housing isn’t taking decisive action.Sectarian abuse has also been witnessed in the area with people being called “Fenians” by a certain family.“Clanmil says it’s taking action but there are people who’ve been a problem for a while and they’re still living here. I don’t think they’re doing enough," Sarah said, "realistically there should be strikes, but people with knives etc should be removed straight away.“How can you feel safe as a single mother with all this going on.”She added: “When I was looking for a house I had to be interviewed, so I don’t know how these people got in with criminal records.“Even today I seen the police here arresting people, it’s just constant now.“But they’re not going to force me out because I like living here.”Police responseResponding to the latest incident and addressing residents’, a PSNI spokesperson said that on Thursday, th July, police received a report of an altercation and anti-social behaviour in the Baliniska Heights area of Derry.On arrival of police there was no sign of this altercation. However, police spoke to a number of persons in the area.Police also aware of a video that was posted onto a social media . Enquiries are ongoing into these reports.Inspector John Moore said: “We will take a strong and proactive stance against anti-social behaviour.“I would like to reassure the local community that we will deal with any offending behaviour in a robust manner.“We are always here to listen to community concerns and are aware of the effects this type of behaviour can have. The support of local people, community and voluntary representatives are essential ingredients to help improve the quality of le for the local residents.“We will continue to work in partnership with our local council and elected representatives as well as community reps and Community Safety Wardens to address the concerns of the local community.“Anyone with any concerns regarding anti-social behaviour should contact police on .”Legal actionIn a statement to the Derry News, a spokesperson for Clanmil Housing said it takes the security and safety of its tenants very seriously, and invests heavily to ensure people feel safe in their homes.“We have been working with the PSNI to deal with a small number of households whose unacceptable behaviour has been unsettling this neighbourhood. We have been taking, and are continuing to take, action against those involved. As a result, a number of these people no longer live at this development and legal action is ongoing against others,” she added.“We are committed to safeguarding the confidentiality of the people who live in our homes and cannot comment on inidual tenants.“Following this recent incident we are meeting with the PSNI to pursue action against those identied in the video. We would ask anyone who witnessed the incident to contact us and the PSNI to assist with our investigations”

title: Cormac delivers at Irish Open
story: ARDGLASS golfer Cormac Sharvin has just had the biggest week of his le.The  year-old was the top Irish finisher at the Dubai Duty Free Irish Open at Lahinch.He finished joint th place on nine-under par to earn the biggest payday of his le, pocketing a cheque for euro,.It was almost three times the amount he has earned on the European Challenge Tour so far this season.Unfortunately, he missed out on securing a dream spot at next weekrsquos Open Championship at Portrush.After signing off with a final round  on Sunday he said: ldquoI felt I didnrsquot play much dferent from the first three days. I just missed it on the wrong side too many times, but all in all, itrsquos a pretty good week.ldquoItrsquos a step in the right direction for sure. It shows I can compete out here.ldquoMy confidence has been pretty high, but itrsquos definitely going to boost that a little.ldquoItrsquos my first time being in contention on the European Tour so Irsquom proud of the way I handled myself on and off the golf course.Sharvin, who turned professional after being a member of the winning Britain and Ireland Walker Cup team in , received huge support from friends and family who travelled to the Co Clare venue.Ranked th in the world before the championship began, Sharvin, who mainly plies his trade on the Challenge Tour, cut the figure of someone who belongs on a bigger stage.He has a classic swing, drives superbly, has a tidy short game and possesses a superb temperament.ldquoI really felt like I took it one shot at a time out there and did that really well, he enthused.A top ten finish would have earned Sharvin a ticket into this weekrsquos Scottish Open andthe potential to claim one of the three spots on offer to next weekrsquos Open at Portrush.ldquoIrsquove tried not to get too bogged down with results and outcome, and thatrsquos just going to come from the process of what Irsquove been doing the last year and a half, trying to get to the next level, he explained.ldquoI know therersquos more there and that will give me confidence..prettyPhoto

title: Dee and Mackenzie never take a breather
story: THE Murray family began the first of what was to prove an historic and richly rewarding week in athletics circles when they took part in the latest North Down Track and Field event on Tuesday night at Bangor.Mackenzie really set the standard for what was to follow when, after competing in the kg shot putt in which he scored . metres, he then proceeded to set a new PB .. in the ,m race in which he was second overall, in a field of  which contained several top quality adult runners.Dee, meantime, was in equally good form setting a new PB of .. for the k race, was only  seconds behind the race winner.Lucy OrsquoNeill also took part in the m U- girlsrsquo sprint and later scored an ever-improving .m in the U- girlsrsquo shot putt, an encouraging warm up for next weekendrsquos All Ireland TF championships in Tullamore.GreyabbeyAlready one of the most prolic and competitive duos anywhere, not only in the number of races participated in, but in terms of miles travelled to meetings, the father and son pairing then made the trip to Greyabbey on Friday night to take part in the two races there.Dee opted for the k and Mackenzie, having no choice, as the rules presently restrict him to the k distance, gave it a real go. He crossed the finish line in ., in sixth place overall, but first U-, a real eye-catching performance out of  finishersMeanwhile, Dee was not letting the side down as he again proved best in his age group, clocking yet another sub  time, his clocking of . was also good enough for overall seventh out of the  finishers.Ford kNewcastle was the venue for a nearer home race on Friday night and several East Down men and women took advantage of the opportunity to warm up for the action in Delamont the next day.Gordy Graham took third place overall in . a mere  seconds behind winner, Newcastlersquos David OrsquoFlaherty, while Catherine OrsquoConnor was second female in . to Gordyrsquos cousin, Laura Graham, who won in .. Paul Lloyd was st in . and Donal Smith placed th in  minutes on the button, out of a total of  runners.DelamontAs Van Morrison once said: ldquoMy momma told me therersquod be days like this,Thus was described East Downrsquos fantastic day out in Delamont on Saturday in the  X k relays, a new and exciting event organised by the Daye Brothers aka Atlas Running, which required teams of five runners each, with each one running a klap as the hot and hilly trails and paths around Delamont were described.At one point we thought we wouldnrsquot have enough runners to fill three teams so to get four teams of five representing East Down was pretty damn impressive.Some pretty impressive performances from the East Down gang as well with victories for the menrsquos A team and the mixed team and third in the all female team.Massive well done to all involved especially the team captain, Deirdre Weatherall who rallied the troops with carrots and sticks and a promise of ice creams, that did not materialise.All agreed that she did a fine job of getting  names in the hat and in the right place at the right time. It was great to see also that several relative newcomers to the club, Gillian and Gerard Grant, Donal Smith, Michael Morrissey and Alison Graham are happy to get involved with some of the older hands and the younger ones to enjoy the delights that a team relay can bring.Performances of the day have to be shared by Gavin Hynds whose third leg run for the EDAC male B team, which effectively hauled them up from last place to th.His time of . for the leg was only bettered by runners from the top two teams on the day, and by Neil Curran, the anchor leg runner for the EDAC A team.His final leg of . only put paid to the battling St Peterrsquos AC quintet during the final lap. The Lurgan team, which had held the lead from the start were understandably disappointed, but the EDAC squad deserved their win.Track and fieldOn to Sunday and it was our juvenile members who had to make the long journey to Tullamore in Co Offally to take part in the All Ireland T F Championships.Spread over two weekends, it therefore means that, for some, there are two journeys to the heart of Ireland on consecutive weekends.Thank you to all the parents for driving all these miles. Your efforts are greatly appreciated by everyone in the club and especially by the athletes themselvesNevertheless, it proved a great day at Tullamore at the first of three days of action with the sun shining for a nice change.East Down had four athletes taking part all in the m, but in two dferent age groups. In the U- race Anna Gardiner and Lucy Foster both ran in separate heats with both finishing in sixth position.The top three in each heat qualied automatically for the final later in the day along with the fastest two finishers outside the top six.Unfortunately, both EDAC girls missed out on qualication, but they ran super races with Lucy gaining a PB of .. and Anna running ...Lauren Madine and Kirsti Foster both competed in the U- race with both winning their heats and automatically qualying for the final later in the day.A last minute change of time table meant the final was brought forward by an hour so that meant quick warm-ups and back on the track was not the ideal preparation that would normally take place before an All-Ireland final.Nonetheless, the two girls put their minds to it and gave it their best shot. Having two out of eight from one club in an All-Ireland final is an achievement in itself.Kirsti came fourth overall in .., just missing a medal by tenths of a second. Lauren had to settle for seventh in . as she was hampered by ankle issues which had developed after her heat.Well done to all four for their efforts. All to be repeated on Sunday when the same quartet run in the ,s. They will be joined by Kara Trainor running in the m and Lucy OrsquoNeill in the shot.Great Ross runThis is an annual event comprising k, k and half marathon races based in Ardboe, Co Tyrone and is increasing in popularity every year.There was a total of over  runners spread across the three events and despite her exertions on Saturday, Deirdre Weatherall and fellow spectator on Saturday and Niamh Kellett made their way to the secluded village of Ardboe, which hosts the races every year.Deirdre didnrsquot show any signs of fatigue as she romped home in sixth place in .. in the half marathon. Niamh, however, turned up the heat in the half, finishing second female overall in a time of ....prettyPhoto

title: Department ‘to approve’ next step in bypass plans
story: PROGRESS on Ballynahinchrsquos proposed multi-million pound bypass could take a hugely signicant step forward before the end of the year.The Department of Finance is expected to approve the eagerly-awaited projectrsquos economic appraisal by December which is viewed as a critical step in the process ahead of the required capital funding being released.And while the permanent secretary at the Department of Infrastructure mdash which will oversee the construction of the bypass mdash has warned that the necessary funding has not yet been made available, progress on the poundm scheme is being welcomed.Roads officials say that development work on the near two-mile scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads is progressing, with work already completed on a major archaeological investigation along parts of the route.The Department of Infrastructure says the preparation of the schemersquos economic appraisal report is continuing with Department of Finance approval for the document due to be sought before the end of the year.Officials have explained that in order to advance the bypass schemersquos state of readiness, preparatory work on contract documents is ongoing to ldquominimise the time required to initiate a procurement competition, should funding become available for construction.The officials have also stressed that progression of the bypass to the procurement and construction stages depends on clearing so-called statutory procedures and available funding.The multi-million pound bypass is designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.It is also proposed that a section of the bypass will pass under part of the Crossgar Road with a  metre long bridge constructed to take traffic over Ballynahinch River.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the bypass where the major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.The bypass, which would be the single biggest road scheme ever constructed in the district mdash is expected to take in excess of  months to build, with roads officials insisting it will greatly benefit both strategic and local road users by reducing journey times and improving road safety.They are also confident the schemersquos economic assessment demonstrates the bypass would provide a good economic .Strangford MLA Peter Weir has welcomed progress on the proposed multi-million pound bypass project, calling for the funding to pave the way for its delivery to be made available.He said speaking to residents in Ballynahinch, he is often told of the need for the proposed bypass to ease ldquoterrible traffic congestion at junctions in the town centre.The Assemblyman added: ldquoI welcome continued progress, albeit slow, to make this scheme shovel ready and will continue to lobby for funding for this important infrastructure project for the town.Rowallane councillor, Billy Walker, is also keen to see progress to deliver the bypass which he believes can play a major role in helping kick-start Ballynahinch town centrersquos economic regeneration.ldquoWe need the bypass to rid the town centre of increasing gridlock and on the main approach roads. Ballynahinch is used as a gateway by visitors to Newcastle and the wider Mournes area in particular and we need to see work on the bypass starting as soon as possible, he said.Cllr Walker argued that the current congestion is hampering new retail and commercial investment in Ballynahinch and believes the provision of the new bypass represents a ldquowin win for everyone..prettyPhoto

title: Down close in on last four
story: DOWN camogs took another step towards qualication for the semi-finals when they blitzed Carlow at Pairc Esler on Saturday afternoon.The home side started in a hurry and stormed into a - to - interval lead, Carlowrsquos only scores coming from two pointed frees.Down were strong in all departments, but they had the star of the show in Portaferryrsquos Niamh Mallon, who helped herself to -, with only three points coming from frees.Mallon received great support from Castlewellanrsquos Sorcha McCartan who helped set Down on their way with a cracking goal in the th minute to put her side - to - clear.Mallon grabbed Downrsquos second goal just after the break and a double from Catherine McGourty was the icing on the cake as the Downmanagement team emptied their bench.The only negative on the day came when Sara Louise Carr had to leave the action in the first half with what appeared to be a calf injury and she must now be a serious doubt for the big game with Derrry on July .Down sit top of their group alongside Tipperary with Derry only a point behind and a win against their Ulster rivals would surely secure a place in the last four.Down -Carlow -ALL-IRELAND ICC.prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C July 17%2C 1979
story: CASTLEWELLAN mdash Stormont officials were keeping tight-lipped this week about the prospect of finding new employment for  workers who have been dramatically paid off at two textile factories in the Castlewellan area.Redundancy notices went sent out last week to employees of the Moss Lane Spinning Company in Castlewellan and Standard Mills of Annsborough mdash but there is a chance they may be re-employedmoves to attract a new company to the vacated premises are successful.The official receiver, Mr Noel Stewart, who is the man heading the search for a new owner, said the two factories mdash operating as a joint company mdash had been plagued by ldquocatastrophic losses during the last  months.He stressed that he was optimistic that a new owner will be found and said the Department of Commerce had indicated that it will give every assistance to get the factories open again.A spokesman for the Department would only say that efforts were being made to get factories re-opened, but would not state the level of success.ldquoWe are trying to get another company to move into the premises at Castlewellan and Annsborough, but I am not prepared to say more than that at the moment, he said.Castlewellan councillor, Mr Eamonn OrsquoNeill, slammed the decision to close the factories and said it was a disaster for the area.Mr OrsquoNeill said he wanted immediate action to cope with the grim unemployment problem facing the people of Castlewellan and Annsborough.ldquoThe overall situation was poor before this dramatic turn of affairs, but the close of these two factories makes the situation disastrous, he said.ldquoThere is now no worthwhile employment opportunity on any reasonable scale in the area. This is a situation which calls for immediate action by all relevant government departments, public bodies and interested parties to encourage, promote and attract new employment to the area, he added.BRYANSFORD mdash On a day when there were ten separate attacks on Post Office property throughout the province, Bryansford Post Office was the target for a terrorist bomb and several post office cables in the area were cut.Last Tuesday the telephone operator received an anonymous callfrom a male at .am warning that a bomb had been planted at the post office.Local police went to the scene where they found that a booby-trap bomb had been left in a waste paper basket outside. An Army technical officer later arrived and the bomb was successfully defused.Around the same time Post Office cables were cut at Dromara Road and Castlewellan Road in Clough.NEWCASTLE mdash Fears that Newcastle would be overwhelmed by a wave of crime and vice during the holiday period proved unfounded, with the resort enjoying an ldquoextremely quiet period.The RUC said before the Twelfth holidays began that they would be swamping the provincersquos major holiday resorts, including Newcastle, in a bid to crack down on the growing problems of teenage drinking and drug-taking.Newcastle had no major incidents or arrests, except for four Belfast youths who are helping police with their inquiries into shoplting at the Gt House of Mourne on July .A police spokesman stressed, however, that patrols were stepped up during the holiday period, especially during weekends, chiefly because the population of the resort doubled during the summer months.Police said violence was the most common side effect of teenage drinking and they had asked publicans, off licence owners and hotels to be extra vigilant.The spokesman added that the police determination to crack down could only succeed with the help of the people who sold the drink.KILLYLEAGH mdash The Dunmore Hotel in Killyleagh changed hands over the holiday period and it may also be changing its name. The new owners are Mr Paul Green and his we Nancy, from Killinchy, and they have taken over the hotel from Mr Harry Briggs.The hotel was sold for an undisclosed sum of money, but it is believed to be in six figures. The new owners intend to extend and renovate the hotel, but hope that all work can be carried out without closing down the hotel.The short term plans include adding nine new bedrooms at the rear and extensively renovating the present accommodation.The owners intend to keep the present name for the time being, but they are contemplating reverting to the original name of the hotel, lsquoThe Treesrsquo.STRANGFORD mdash Shore sports proved every bit as popular as the sailing events at Strangford Regatta last week.Hundreds of holidaymakers flocked to the village to watch people of all age groups taking part in a host of events in the hot summer sun.The wide spectrum of events made it a day of fierce competition and fun for competitors and spectators alike and the organisers say they were amazed at the success of the sporting programme.Events included a fancy dress competition, round the houses race, rowing race and races for married men and women. Amusements were also provided for the children.PORTAFERRY mdash The Strangford to Portaferry swim was one of the highlights of Portaferry Gala Week, which began on Sunday and continues through until Saturday.The swim against the current, which is believed to be one of the fastest in Europe, took the most out of all eight competitors, who ranged in age from  to .But for Jacqui McIntyre, of Bangor Swimming Club, the swim proved comparatively easy. With her time of  minutes and  seconds, she won the ladiesrsquo section and also recorded the fastest time overall.The gala began on Sunday with a fun run and boat sea angling competition. It concludes this Saturday with the final of the talent competition and an open air dance.MOURNES mdash The Mourne Mountains are alive to the sound of music mdash music with a message which is about building bridges across the world.The area was the cockpit for an international roadshow arranged and rehearsed at break-neck speed around camp fires. More than  YMCA members were given seven days to prepare themselves for their song and dance routine.They were at the YMCArsquos Green Hill complex perched at the foot of the Mournes above Newcastle. It is the first time that the camp, with participants coming from Holland, Spain, Germany, Australia, America, Britain and the Republic of Ireland, has been staged there.SAINTFIELD mdash A  year-old Saintfield boy was taken to Downe Hospital last Tuesday after he had been involved in an accident. Patrick Clarke, from Ballynahinch Road, ran from a laneway into the path of a car which travelling along Comber Street.CROSSGAR mdash Crossgarrsquos David McClurg won the Jersey Cup at Tyrone Farming Societyrsquos annual show. David lted the cup for the best Jersey animal and also achieved first place with his Jersey cow in the pedigree section.GOLF mdash Captainrsquos Day at Ardglass Golf Club went down a treat with Oliver McMahonrsquos  points winning the major prize in a very enjoyable competition.Once again the Captainrsquos Day lived up to all the traditions of a happy and memorable day. The captain, Dr Dan McDaniel, the members, guests and visitors all had a great time.The competition began at am with the appearance of a magnum of champagne on the first tee mdash much to the delight of the starter, Ivor Ray, and the first two contestants, Brendan Rodgers and Basil Coburn.GAA mdash Downrsquos minor footballers go in search of their second Ulster title in three years when they play Tyrone in the final at Clones on Sunday.This is a game that has all the ingredients of a thriller. In last yearrsquos semi-final Down, then reigning All-Ireland champions, surprisingly went under to Tyrone at Casement Park, so now the Mourne boys have a chance to get revenge..prettyPhoto

title: Haydn has right stuff
story: SPA hosted the annual St Johnrsquos GAC Golf Classic fundraiser last week on a course described by organiser Eugene OrsquoBoyle as ldquojust fabulous.The overall winner was Haydn Gibson, who carded  points to take the GUI-affiliated prize while non-GUI player Neil Stranney playing off a handicap of  accumulated a phenomenal  points to win that category by a mile.Patrick McCluskey, Hugh Bonner, Eugene OrsquoBoyle and Brendan Malone won the GUI team prize with Darren Savage, Harry McMullan, Karl McMullan and Conor Morgan the leading non-GUI team.Speaking at the presentation of prizes Mr OrsquoBoyle said the new arrangement this year of a shotgun start seemed to have worked extremely well and brought such positive feedback from the competitors it was likely it would be repeated in future years.He thanked everyone at Spa Golf Club, including the staff for their hospitality and cooperation in organising the St Johnrsquos event, and paid tribute to the generosity of all the sponsors and in particular Owen Flynn, of Green Energy Wind.Mr OrsquoBoyle said the Drumnaquoile GAA club ldquofelt privileged at being accorded the opportunity to play on such a ldquofabulous course as Spa and complimented members and officials on the great work that had been carried out over the past number of years.Sponsor Mr Flynn said it was great to be part of such a wonderful event as the GAA Classic and to see so many competitors enjoying the day.He described the Spa course as a credit to the management and staff at the golf club.St Johnrsquos chairman Mr Jimmy Laverty said such an event could not take place without the support and goodwill of all the sponsors and thanked all his members for their hard work in planning and supervising the day.ResultsGUI: st Haydn Gibson, nd Sean title: Libraries NI invites kids to get reading
story: PARENTS who are keen for their children to keep up reading over the summer school break should take note of this yearrsquos Big Summer Read.The annual reading initiative is a free programme which encourages children and teens to continue reading throughout the summer months.Libraries NI is inviting children aged  and under to sign up to the Big Summer Read by calling into any of the public or mobile libraries across Northern Ireland.The first local session kicks off with a summer reading club starting at Castlewellan Library today at pm. On Friday in Downpatrick Library, therersquos a Big Summer Read Lego session at pm and again at the same time on Monday. At Comber Library therersquos a Storytime and Craft session on the same day at pm.Also on Monday there will be Storytime and Craft at Ballynahinch Library for children aged - at pm finishing with a Fun with The Dogs Trust event next Wednesday, also at pm.A reading chart and record card will be given to every child on their first visit to the library during July and August.Throughout the summer, children are invited to read as many books as possible recording each book on their reading chart. At the end of the summer, participants will receive a special certicate in recognition of their reading achievement.For more information on the Big Summer Read, details of free events and activities taking place in your local library and how you can sign up today, call into your nearest library or go to the Libraries NI website www.librariesni.org.uk..prettyPhoto

title: Liz celebrates Barbara’s day
story: IT was the turn of the ladies to take centre stage at Crossgar Golf Club on Saturday when Liz Murray won Barbara Woottonrsquos Lady Captainrsquos Day competition with  points.With the weather set fair and the course in great condition, everyone knew that only their best golf was going to get them in the mix.Maeve Fay continued her good form winning the front nine prize, but wavered on the back nine whilst Sheila Hillis ,after a poor start, got it together to snatch the back nine prize.Nuala Hynds played superb golf to sign for  points and secure the section B prize with Monica Magee similarly playing well to win section A with a respectable  points.The Past Captainsrsquo Trophy went to Barbara Clarke whilst Isobel Hyde won the committee award. Guest Prize was won by Hilary McHenry with Maeve Fay winning the longest drive.The menrsquos section was every bit as competitive with John Lyons setting the early pace with  points before Tucker Price continued his good form to take the lead signing for  points. The winner, though, was Neil Hanvey who was securing his second win of the season with a superb  points.Davy Watson again won the gross, restricting himself to  strokes for a great round. The menrsquos guest prize went the way of Brian Curry with Tony Morgan winning the nearest the pin. Evergreen Malachy Magee put the young hotshots in their place winning the longest drive.Barbara Wootton, thanked all those who had helped her in any way to make the day such a success and those present after the prize giving helped her happily dance the night away..prettyPhoto

title: Local owners among Downpatrick prizes
story: MONDAYrsquoS family fun race day at Downpatrick drew its usual large attendance in perfect conditions.The seven-race card of six hurdle races and a bumper provided two locally owned winners.The first of them came in the fourth race of the day, the Irish Jockeys Association Mares Maiden Hurdle.Inishbel, in the well known colours of popular retired Moira bookmaker Pat McCartan, with Bryan Cooper in the saddle, won in a good finish over the Colin McBratney-trained Laureate, ridden by Adam Short. Third here was So Enjoy. The former point-to-pointer is trained in Co Wexford by Colin Bowe. SP:   fav   -.The second local winner came in the fth race, the Digita Agency Supporting St Patrickrsquos Coastal RideHandicap Hurdle.Course winner Canadian Steel, who had finished third at Sligo the previous day, put up a fantastic show under Conor Orr, to hold off the late challenge of another course winner in King of Aran, ridden by Danny Mullins, with the McBratney-trained Caerleon Kate third under Bryan Cooper having a rare ride for the Crossgar trainer.The winner is owned by Shauna Kelly and is trained by her husband, Noel, who has made such a good job of this horse since he purchased it from Drumanessrsquo David Aiken last year.The feature race of the day was the Plus  Print, remembering Tony Oakes MBE Hurdle, but out of the original five declared runners only three took part and two of these were trained by Gordon Elliott.Avenir DrsquoUne Vie, with Rachael Blackmore in the saddle, made all to beat the Denis OrsquoRegan-ridden Lethal Steps with Hammerstein third. Henry De Bromhead, who has a good record at the track, trains the winner in Waterford so the long trip paid off, but sad to see the lack of support for the good prize money.Front running tactics also paid off in the Tony Patterson SportsgroundsMaiden Hurdle with Donal McInerney making every post a winning one on Construct to get the verdict over Steel Cap and Guttural. The winner is trained by John McConnell in Co Meath. SP:   joint favourite,   -.The easiest winner of the day came in the North Down Marques Handicap Hurdle with the   favourite Peaches and Cream, with Jonathan Moore in the saddle, storming home  s clear of the Neil McKnight owned and trained Greenandwhitearmy and the long time clear leader, Alan McCaldinrsquos Santa Anna.The winner is trained in Co Meath by the inform Gavin Cromwell who was at the Killarney meeting. This race had the largest line out of the day with  runners.Adam Short came in for a nice spare ride when replacing Danny Hand on Happy Lad in the Downpatrick Racecourse Maiden Hurdle.The winner is owned and trained in Co Meath by Hugh Finegan, who doesnrsquot have a great deal of success. The top weight came home five s clear of Hello Pilgrim, trained by Colin Bowe and the mount of Rachael Blackmore. Third was Killintiese. SP:      .The best finish of the day came in the concluding race, the two NMs Bumper Race, with only a short head separating the first two past the judge Andrew McKeever.Seven took part and racing into the final furlong nothing was travelling better than local jockey Deckie Lavery in Mystery Stowaway but his mount kept hanging and Jamie Codd came with a fantastic challenge up along the stands rail on Saint or Sinner to just snatch victory at the post.Half aback in third position came Aine OrsquoConnor on Coosan Clover.The winner is trained by the champion trainer at the course over the past four years, Gordon Elliott.Acting stewards were Alison Millar , Thomas Breen, Laurence McFerran and Frankie Fitzsimons.It was a busy day for my press room friend Justin OrsquoHanlon as he was also commenting at the course for the first time in place of regular Jerry Hannan, who was at Killarney.The local racing world was shocked to learn on Sunday that Paddy Allen had passed away at the age of .Paddy, of Gortinamoney Farm, Moira, had run the much used schooling gallops and schooling grounds since the sudden passing of his father Jim a couple of years ago and had only recently opened a new state-of-the-art schooling gallop. He will be much missed by all those that knew him.It was also sad to learn that Lucy Horner, who rode for George Stewart a few years ago in point-to-points when based in the army at Lisburn, passed away at the age of  in England. She was a former champion lady jockey.Carol Ross, we of the late trainer and amateur jockey Cecil, who did so much for point-to-points, also passed away atthe weekend following a long illness. To all the aboversquos family and friends, sympathy is extended..prettyPhoto

title: New Castlewellan Forest Park trail
story: A NEW family discovery trail has been launched in Castlewellan Forest Park, thanks to money from the Woodland Trustrsquos Tree of the Year competitionThe Annesley Garden mdash located within the stunning park mdash is well known for its international collection of trees, with the new discovery trail taking mini nature detectives around the world as they meet trees from across the globe such as Argentina, Japan, Tasmania and Australia.Taking centre stage is a  year old giant redwood reigning from Calornia.Most redwoods have eyes only for the sky as they shoot to over  metres tall, but Castlewellanrsquos behemoth grew width ways instead to form  inter-connecting stems.Last year, the magnicent redwood topped the public pole to become Northern Irelandrsquos Tree of the Year after being nominated by tree enthusiasts Dr Sally Montgomery of Castlewellan Futuresrsquo Heritage Group and Ann Irwin of Arboretum Regeneration Group.The competition prize money was put to good use by installing the nature trail for everyone to enjoy.Dr Montgomery described the tree of the year competition as a ldquogreat way for anyone to celebrate a tree that is special to them.ldquoNorthern Ireland has hundreds of amazing trees with special memories and they all have a story to tell, she continued.ldquoWinning the competition helped raise the profile of the Annesley Garden and has enabled us to create new educational resources to help engage the next generation with the wonders of our fabulous trees.ldquoI encourage everyone to take five minutes to nominate their favourite tree for this yearrsquos competition and celebrate naturersquos giants.The Woodland Trustrsquos Tree annual tree competition aims to celebrate and shout about the best trees that Northern Ireland has to offer.Iniduals, groups and organisations are encouraged to share the myths and memories of their best-loved tree.Whether your tree simply brightens up your garden or has been around for thousands of years, the Trust wants to hear about it.The winning tree will benefit from a tree care award of up to pound,, with runners up receiving pound, which might assist a health check from a specialist, educational materials or a community event in celebration of the tree.Detailed information about the competition and nominations visit www.woodlandtrust.org.uk treeoftheyear. Nominations must be submitted by this Friday..prettyPhoto

title: Regeneration plans to regenerate buildings in boost for Irish Street
story: WORK to secure all the necessary land required to pave the way for an ambitious multi-million pound regeneration initiative in Downpatrickrsquos Irish Street in may not be completed until the end of the year.The townrsquos former police base mdash which forms part of the overall development site mdash has already been purchased, but there are a number of adjacent buildings and pockets of land which need to be bought, it has been confirmed.The old police station enjoys protected status and will remain a key feature of the proposed redevelopment project which, in addition to new retail and commercial space, could also include an element of housing provision.Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Department for Communities are driving the regeneration project, with suggestions that the old police station could be utilised as an attractive entrance feature.The heritage value of the Irish Street area is something council officials are not only keen to preserve, but build upon as they work with the government department to maximise the potential of the development site which also includes the Irish Street car park.Ambitious plans for a new retail and commercial centre at the Irish Street site, which stretches back as far as St Patrickrsquos Avenue, were unveiled in December  with local council and government officials working to deliver the multi-million pound town centre regeneration initiative designed to bring new investment to the town.Council officials are determined to deliver the major scheme and are excited at the development potential the Irish Street site offers and want to maximise its potential.They have confirmed that they are in the final throes of acquiring all the land they need before a development brief can be compiled and sent out to seek expressions of interest from the private and commercial sectors.While council officials hope to conclude this process shortly, they have admitted that it could be the end of the year before everything is done and dusted to pave the way for a major redevelopment site in the heart of the town.Parking provision is also expected to form a key part of the Irish Street redevelopment initiative with any spaces potentially lost as a result of the investment expected to be provided where.Council officials favour a mixed use of the sprawling site featuring retail, commercial and residential developments designed to ldquobring the heart back into Downpatrick.Given ious investment plans for the Newry area, senior council officials are keen to show their backing for new development in the county town via new investment in Irish Street.Leading retailers including Marks and Spencer and Home Bargains, along with several other big names, are reportedly keen to invest in Downpatrick, but at present cannot identy suitable accommodation to meet their respective needs.Council officials hope that once the development brief for the Irish Street site is completed, outlining what they would like to see developed at this part of town, it will generate signicant interest.The brief aims to encourage developers to come forward to redevelop the area, while there are also plans to work alongside the local community on the design of the site to maximise not only the sitersquos potential, but its historical heritage.Council officials are confident the proposed redevelopment can act as a catalyst for additional town centre investment, increasing footfall and providing a boost for existing Downpatrick businesses which have been at the backbone of the townrsquos economy for many years.They say the development brief is designed to encourage third parties to come forward with viable proposals for the Irish Street site that will result in sustainable regeneration in the town centre..prettyPhoto

title: Suzie nets bronze and sets her sights on silver
story: SAINTFIELDrsquoS Suzie Cave has just ed home from the European Triathle Championships with a bronze medal.Triathle, a shoot, swim and run competition, is a new discipline for the civil servant as she has concentrated on the modern pentathlon in recent years.ldquoMy focus now is the Traithle World Championships in Florida in October, but before then I will hopefully have both the laser run Europeans in Germany and Masters Modern Pentathlon European Championships in Hungary, she said.Coincidentally, Suzie also took part in the Laser Run City Tour the next day mdash a run and shoot mdash and won it.Madeira provided the idyllic setting for the triathlete championships and Suzie enjoyed every minute of the competition.ldquoThe championships were an experience and a half. I knew the competition level would be majorly raised ndash so I was approaching them with the attitude that they would be good experience for me mdash I did not have any expectations, she added.ldquoI went with the attitude to just to do my own race and enjoy being there mdash that anything after that would be a bonus. I knew with this only being the third time I had done triathle, I really couldnrsquot expect much against the pros.ldquoSo, to medal at this event was one of the biggest surprises I have had in my le. I knew I was strong at the British level, but I had never done an international before to know where I might lie. Irsquom still in shock, she confessed.The highly-dedicated athlete didnrsquot start the competition that well, but she recovered well to lt bronze.ldquoI had a bad first shoot, which I put down to nerves. I then I had to work my way from the back over the next few circuits.Good shoots and strong running in the next three circuits is what helped to pull me up to bronze, she continued.ldquoMadeira was amazing. Stunning scenery and great food, most importantly.The weather was fantastic, the water was calm, pretty warm and clear, which was ideal, considering this was my first time swimming outdoors and not in pool.It was very much a learning experience for me too.No one is more surprised at Suziersquos success than Suzie herself, but she admits that she still has a lot to learn.ldquoIrsquom extremely surprised how well I have adapted to the sport. I knew it could play to my strengths eventually, but being new to it, I wasnrsquot expecting to be as competitive just yet. I still have so much to learn and improve on, which makes it exciting, she enthused.ldquoOver the next few months I will have to chat with coaches and make a decision on the event I want to focus on the most.I will continue training all five events, but I think my main aim will be the Triathle Worlds in October in Florida.Suzie now feels that the time is right to put her toes into local waters so that she can improve her swimming discipline.ldquoNow Irsquove had a taste of open water swimming, its time to brave the Northern Ireland waters, so I can perfect my technique and become more efficient at sighting and swimming round buoys, she continued.ldquoI will also be back in the gym building on my strength again. Itrsquos an important part of my training which I have to not over do during competition.ldquoI cannot wait for World Championships in Florida, she beamed,ldquoThe competition level will be fierce, so Irsquoll be going with no expectations. My parents couldnrsquot make it out to Madeira, but- luckily it was all streamed live so they could watch it from home.ldquoHowever, they are going to come out to Florida with me. In, fact I think a number of my family and friends will come. Not to see me of course, any excuse for a trip to Florida.ldquoI have only been to New York for a couple of days before so Irsquom excited to see more of America.The competition is in Tampa Bay, which I found out is only a few hours drive from Orlando. I think Irsquom mostly excited about that..prettyPhoto

title: Thousands attend Twelfth in Crossgar
story: THOUSANDS of Orangemen, bandsmen and their families travelled to Crossgar for last Fridayrsquos Twelfth of July demonstration when two local politicians were praised for their work in the community.Brethren from host district Lecale were joined by others from Castlewellan, Saintfield, Comber and Ballynahinch and sisters from the Womenrsquos Loyal Orange Lodges and supporting bands for the annual Battle of the Boyne commemoration.During his address at the demonstration field, Grand Chaplain of the Grand Orange Lodge of Ireland, the Rev Dr Stanley Gamble, highlighted the efforts of Rowallane SDLP councillor Terry Andrews and his DUP colleague Billy Walker.Cllr Andrews, who is Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos vice-chairman, attended the parade as a spectator and was delighted to catch up with the Dr Gamble.During his address, the principal speaker asked Orangemen and women to be ldquoactive in their respective communities. He said as Christians, people are called to be salt and light in their local communities.And, referring to the Sermon on the Mount, Dr Gamble recalled Jesus saying: lsquoYou are the light of the world. Let your light shine. You are the salt of the earth. Be salty.rsquoHe continued: ldquoBeing salt and light in our communities means making a dference and, as iniduals, we can do this as we use our gts and abilities to be a blessing to those around us.ldquoTwo iniduals who have excelled at this are local councillors Terry Andrews and Billy Walker who have worked together to make a dference in our community, helping to move us in a better direction, he said.Last Friday was the first time in  years that Crossgar hosted the annual mid Down twelfth demonstration, with the villagersquos own Cumberland True Blue Orange Lodge No  leading the possession through the heart of the village.The local Orangemen were accompanied by Crossgar Young Defenders Flute Band from the assembly field on the Downpatrick Road, along the .mile route through the village to the demonstration field at the Killyleagh Road.The parade coincided with a number of signicant milestones in the history of local Orangeism, with Cumberland True Blues Lodge marking its th anniversary, as well as the th anniversary of the building of the villagersquos Orange Hall.Among the other  Lodges and  bands taking part were Inch LOL No  whose banner was recently named lsquoBanner of the Yearrsquo at the annual Orange awards.Local band members from Hollymount Pipe Band on parade are celebrating the centenary of their formation in  and Spa Accordion Band members were resplendent in new unorms.And on a day of anniversaries, Ballygowan LOL No  and Comber Old Standard LOL No  celebrated their th anniversaries..prettyPhoto

title: fermanagh peer calls mlas get back work
story: A Fermanagh peer has said people are ldquofed up to the teeth at the ongoing impasse at Stormont and called on MLAs here to get back to work.Viscount Brookeborough, The Queenrsquos Lord Lieutenant for County Fermanagh, told the House of Lords last week that ldquo per cent of people in Northern Ireland want a restoration of our devolved Parliament.ldquo per cent of the normal people in Northern Ireland are totally and absolutely frustrated by our political parties not getting together. We should forget who is to blame.ldquoThe people around us at home are fed up to the teeth with the politicians whom they elected to our Assembly being, for whatever reason, incapable of sorting something out for us, he said.Directing his remarks at his fellow peers, Viscount Brookeborough said: ldquoAlthough you are no longer Assembly Members, go back home and get your parties to agree.ldquoGet there, talk and produce a legitimate Government for us in Northern Ireland. If you do not, you cannot blame the Government herethey have to take measures in lieu of all of you, he said.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: grace s legacy one goodness laughter says fr brian fermanagh favourite laid rest
story: Veteran entertainer Brendan Grace was loved by everybody and his only vocation in le was to make people happy, Fermanagh born cleric Father Brian DrsquoArcy told the comedianrsquos funeral mass on Monday.Hundreds of people lined the streets of the Liberties in Dublin to pay their respects to the much-loved Dubliner, who died last week at the age of  after a short illness.Mr. Grace was a frequent visitor to Enniskillen playing the Ardhowen Theatre for many years, including in February of this year.The crowd cheered and applauded and the sang the words of the Dublin Saunter along with the Forget Me Not Choir as his coffin arrived at the Church of St Nicholas of Myra on Francis Street.There was standing-room only for the large crowd of mourners inside the church, while the huge crowd outside the church listened to the mass on speakers.Figures from the music and political world came together to pay tribute to the stand-up comedian and Father Ted star.The actor played Father Fintan Stack in the popular comedy series about three priests and he also starred in the  TV film Brendan Gracersquos Bottler.Comedian Brendan OrsquoCarroll and his we Jenner Gibney, former taoiseach Bertie Ahern, Fianna Fail leader Micheal Martin, entertainer Twink and singer Dickie Rock were among those who attended the mass.Former Ireland international footballer Niall Quinn, singer Daniel OrsquoDonnell and RTErsquos Marty Morrissey and DJ Ronan Collins were also present to pay their respects.The mass began with Gracersquos grandchildren James, Patrick and Aiden, bringing gts to the alter to symbolise the comedianrsquos le. They included a microphone, a book of jokes entitled Amusing Grace and a guitar.Red Hurley, Paddy Cole and Finbar Furey paid a musical tribute to their friend.Irish president Michael D Higgins was represented by his aide de camp Col Liam Condon and Taoiseach Leo Varadkar was represented by his ADC Commandant Caroline Burke.Fr. Brian Darcy, who celebrated the funeral mass, told mourners that the entertainerrsquos memory would forever live on.ldquoBrendan Grace will never die because all of us have enthusiastic, brilliant and long-lasting, le-lasting and le-changing memories of the wonderful man that he was - the humanity of the man, the generosity of the man, the goodness of the man, Fr. Darcy said.He added that Gracersquos legacy to the world would be one of goodness, laughter and generosity.ldquoAll of his vocation in le was quite simply, nothing more, nothing less, than to lt the gloom of the nation and to lt the gloom of the people who came to see him, he said.He continued: ldquoHis only vocation in le was to make people happy.Fr. Darcy, a lelong friend of Grace, told mourners the comedian was a unying force. ldquoEverybody loved Brendan Grace, protestant, catholic, young, old, cultured, uncultured. It didnrsquot matter what you were, he said.Speaking to mourners, Fr. Brian continued: ldquoEducated, non-educated. They all loved Brendan, he said.Grace died last Thursday surrounded by his family, after being diagnosed with lung cancer in recent weeks.He is survived by his we, Eileen, and their four children, Bradley, Melanie, Brendan and Amanda.The entertainer had lived in the US for many years, but ed to his native Dublin in early June, where he was first diagnosed with pneumonia, before his terminal cancer diagnosis. He was due toto the county for a another show next year.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres.
